properties.description: "The Shahnama, written by Abul-Qasim Firdawsi around 1010 AD, is a book containing over 60000 verses of stories and epics that pertain to the history of Persia. Although there are no surviving manuscripts from Firdawsi’s time, there are some from around the 13th to 15th centuries. Each grandson of Timur had a copy of the Shahnama made for them. One grandson, Ibrahim Sultan, has his own copy and is the patron of this copy of the Shahnama. For Ibrahim Sutlan’s copy, there is a preface that documents his story and his life before the start of the original Shahnama writings. Folio 4r falls within this preface and therefore has no relation to any of the Shahnama stories, but only on Sultan’s life experiences (Watson,2018)." (Hebert & Dempsey)

"Unfortunately, there is little context to what exactly is happening or what is depicted in this folio, and all that is written next are just assumptions based on observation. Most or almost all of the figures within the folio are men. This cannot be said with certainty because the original folio seems to have been damaged on the top left area, making it difficult to confidently assume that the two figures depicted are indeed men."

"Assuming that those two figures are indeed men, then almost all of the figures within the folio are looking to the right and seem to have their head bowing down. Five of the men are also on their knees, two on the ground and three on a carpet/mat. The way the men are depicted in this folio gives a melancholy effect, and makes the looker almost assume that some sort of tragedy has taken place or that someone important and dear has passed away. "

"The light blue, almost grey ground further accentuates the point. Moreover, the plant/ bush in the middle of the folio, along with the other plants seen within, are not as bright, vibrant and contrasted with the background as with some of the other folios."

"It can also be seen that on the top right what could be the coffin of the deceased person as there is a sword that is resting upon the coffin, possibly symbolising that the deceased person was a warrior. Although this can be an interpretation, it is somewhat unlikely since the 3 men on the carpet would be bowing their heads towards said coffin, and not to the right of the folio."

"In dividing the work into pages, it will be seen that in, cases where a building is but partially drawn on one page, it is given complete on the adjoining page. In view of the magnitude of the work, the originality of the idea, and the difficulties encountered in carrying it out, it is hoped that if any mistakes or errors have crept into the plates or pages, they will be looked upon with a lenient eye by an indulgent public." (Dry & Compton)
